properties.ariaLabel: Counting circular arrangements of objects permalink

children.value: In high-school mathematics you've probably come across the term
. In its most basic form, combinatorics is about counting the number of ways you can arrange some objects in a particular fashion. For example, to arrange
(distinct) objects in a line, there are
possible permutations. If there are repeated objects, we divide by the permutations of the identical objects. For example arranging the letters of
both repeat twice, so there are
permutations. On the other hand, if we wanted to arrange

, each arrangement can be rotated and it is considered "identical". So we arrange the items in a line and divide by the number of different rotations of these objects (to remove the overcounted arrangements)
What happens when we combine these ideas together? Say we take take
objects, where some are repeating, and arrange them in a circle. An easy example: arrange the letters
in a circle. How many ways can this be done? It's easy to write down every possibility, and we find that there are only two (considering rotation as equivalent):
Image generated using tikz, converted to SVG using pdf2svg, scaled up using inkscape
However if we try to combine the two equations we used above, the number of permutations comes out to be

, but isn't even a whole number! We could try many different examples and attempt formulate a nice equation, but it's not exactly that simple! It turns out there is a nice theorem that gives a general procedure to solve this, but it requires some background in group theory.

In mathematics, Group theory is the study of symmetries, how they interact with each other, and how they interact with other objects. There is a theorem of group that counts the number of "different" elements in a set, given that elements are "not different" when are related by a symmetry (more precisely, a group action). We can apply this to concrete counting problems, by looking at e.g. rotations acting on objects arranged in a circle. This theorem can be extended to extract more information about arrangements, where the calculations are reduced to looking at coefficients of a polynomial.

The following is a quick and brief proof-less introduction to the concepts we will need. The intention is to be a refresher for those who have seen groups before, however, if you are new to these concepts, there should be barely enough to understand (with time) how the counting theorem works.

be a (finite) group acting on a set
This lemma (not actually by Burnside) tells you how many orbits of a group action there are.
be a (finite) group acting on a set
This theorem says that the number of orbits is the

\begin{aligned}
  \sum_{g \in G} |S^g| &= \sum_{g \in G} |\{s \in S: g \cdot s = s\}| \\
  &= |\{(g,s) : g \in G, s \in S, g \cdot s = s\}| \\
  &= \sum_{s \in S} |\op{Stab}(s)| \\
  &= \sum_{s \in S} \frac{|G|}{|G \cdot s|} & \text{(Orbit-Stabilizer Thm)} \\
  &= |G| \sum_{s \in S} |G \cdot s|.
\end{aligned}
can be partitioned into all orbits, so we can instead sum over orbits

\begin{aligned}
  \sum_{g \in G} |S^g|  &= |G| \sum_{s \in S} |G \cdot s| \\
  &= |G| \sum_{A \in S/G} \sum_{s \in A} \frac{1}{|G \cdot s|} \\
  &= |G| \sum_{A \in S/G} \sum_{s \in A} \frac{1}{|A|} \\
  &= |G| \sum_{A \in S/G} 1 \\
  &= |G| |S/G|,
\end{aligned}
This theorem by itself can already be used to solve our problem. Remember that we wanted to arrange the letters
in a circle. We can take

to as our group action, so that each arrangement and all its rotations can be summed up as one orbit. We wanted to know how many of these "different" arrangements (or orbits) there are, which Burnside's lemma tells us. If we let
be all the tuples representing arrangements of
in a line, then the number of orbits under
is the number of "different" arrangements of

This is exactly what we wanted! In fact Burnside's lemma is enough for any version of our problem, but we continue further to explore a theorem by Pólya that generalises this.
Before moving on, note that if we let the set
be the set of all 4-element arrangements of the letters
(with replacement), then Burnside's lemma tells us the number of ways to arrange
on a circle (with replacement). Particularly, orbits of the arrangements of

. Pólya's theorem builds on this by describing the number of circle arrangements of every 4-letter combination of

The main feature of Pólya's theorem is that it distinguishes between 'weights' of particular combinations of colours.

Notice that, even though they have the same weight, these functions don't belong to the same orbit, since

are not rotations of each other. So these weights lose information about the functions, but tells us how many times each letter appears, but nothing about their order. This is perfect for what we want!

Note: we also see that Pólya's theorem is essentially just Burnside's lemma applied to each weight.

You may have noticed that multinomial coefficients are exactly how we were taught to count the permutations of letters with possibly some repeating. So it makes sense that it comes up when counting arrangements of the same letters in a circle.

Notice that we have this kind of polynomial because all the non-identity cycle decompositions are
-cycles. In fact this happens exactly when the number of elements is prime.
This shows that the naïve formula we started with works for non-trivial colourings of a prime number of elements.
Is there a nice general formula we can extract from this theorem? Not really, but we can pull something together.
Briefly, what we need to know is the following. (The first three points find the pattern inventory, and the last point find the desired coefficient.)

How many elements have same cycle size and cycle lengths?

So given a valid list of 'colours'
, the coefficient in the pattern inventory (i.e. the number of arrangements of these colours) looks something like
We only looked at cyclic groups
, but we could use any subgroup of
. For example if we think of reflections of our circular arrangements as "identical", then we can use the dihedral group
. The orbits under the dihedral group is exactly the distinct "circular arrangements" we want.
The theorem can also be applied for various different counting problems, by changing the weights and subgroup of
. For example, Pólya applied this theorem to count the number of isomers of hydrocarbons, which popularised its usage.
This post was based on the following. These are good reading if you want to explore this topic more.
(Polya Enumeration Theorem) MIT PRIMES Project, Sebastian Zhu, Vincent Fan
